(1 comment)
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 662aa6e361f8705cfd91261080324ff0e74778e4

This has some performance and safety implications.  If an outside user can cause an ERROR trace to happen, it's much easier to DOS attack the BMC.  Have you measured any of that?

Also, we're not very careful with when we use ERROR and when we use informational.  Someone would need to audit all of our uses, and ensure that those levels ONLY occurred on internal to the bmc problems, not on bad user data, which I don't think is the case today.

What about a meson option to turn on Error like we have a option to turn on Debug today? I think Error should be internal to the bmc problems, not bad user data, although i'm sure some will need to change..

Maybe this option allows for selecting a level from the 5:

#define BMCWEB_LOG_CRITICAL                                                    \
    if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Critical)        \
    crow::Logger("CRITICAL", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Critical)
// NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
#define BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR                                                       \
    if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Error)           \
    crow::Logger("ERROR", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Error)
// NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
#define BMCWEB_LOG_WARNING                                                     \
    if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Warning)         \
    crow::Logger("WARNING", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Warning)
// NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
#define BMCWEB_LOG_INFO                                                        \
    if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Info)            \
    crow::Logger("INFO", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Info)
// NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
#define BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG                                                       \
    if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Debug)           \
    crow::Logger("DEBUG", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Debug)

> What about a meson option to turn on Error like we have a option to turn on Debug today?

That nobody is allowed to set because it's a security DOS issue?  Doesn't seem like it adds value, or maybe I'm missing something?

> I think Error should be internal to the bmc problems, not bad user data, although i'm sure some will need to change..

This is not true today, although I do agree with you, we could come up with a formal definition like this and audit all of the log statements.

> 
> Maybe this option allows for selecting a level from the 5:
> 
> #define BMCWEB_LOG_CRITICAL                                                    \
>     if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Critical)        \
>     crow::Logger("CRITICAL", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Critical)
> // NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
> #define BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR                                                       \
>     if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Error)           \
>     crow::Logger("ERROR", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Error)
> // NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
> #define BMCWEB_LOG_WARNING                                                     \
>     if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Warning)         \
>     crow::Logger("WARNING", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Warning)
> // NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
> #define BMCWEB_LOG_INFO                                                        \
>     if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Info)            \
>     crow::Logger("INFO", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Info)
> // NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
> #define BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG                                                       \
>     if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Debug)           \
>     crow::Logger("DEBUG", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Debug)

> That nobody is allowed to set because it's a security DOS issue? Doesn't seem like it adds value, or maybe I'm missing something?

I think the value is, more easily debug bmcweb related issues. I think users should be able to enable whatever level of debug they choose. We already allow for enabling logs just not a granular setting

One additional question.

In my approach, the log-level can only be set during the compile time - even with the debugging is enabled, and setLogLevel() is removed.

Should we go back to the previous approach to allow to set log level at the runtime - i.e. keeping setLogLevel() and not using 'if constexpr'?
Why did this move?  The old code ensured that if logging is disabled, none of the strings could ever get into the binary.  As-written, I don't think this code realizes that.

As you and Gunnar suggested, I've introduced a new meson option 
to optionally set the logging-level ('debug' if not set) like
  -Dbmcweb-logging-level=<level>.
  
<level> can be either 'debug', 'info', 'warning', 'error', or 'critical'.
This logging level will be effective if bmcweb-logging is enabled.

Since the logging level is specified as an option, the debugging level is known
during the compile time and thus 'setLogLevel()' is not needed.

In addition, we can optimized Logger class  by using 'constexpr' 
so that the only enabled logging codes are emitted to the binary.

So, I've removed setLogLevel() function, but introduced a constexpr function 

 constexpr static bool checkLoggingLevel(const LogLevel level)
 
 And then I've applied those into BMCWEB_LOG_XXX macros like
 
 // NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
#define BMCWEB_LOG_CRITICAL                                                    \
    if constexpr (crow::Logger::checkLoggingLevel(crow::LogLevel::Critical))	\
    crow::Logger("CRITICAL", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Critical)


// NOLINTNEXTLINE(cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage)
#define BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR                                                       \
    if constexpr (crow::Logger::checkLoggingLevel(crow::LogLevel::Error))	\
    crow::Logger("ERROR", __FILE__, __LINE__, crow::LogLevel::Error)
Limit the subject line to 50 characters From https://cbea.ms/git-commit/
I've modified the commit message to comply the spec.
Tested statement?
The test statement is added
Can you add more detail here?

Description is modified to:

    description: 'Enable output the extended logs whose level can be specified
                  via bmcweb-logging-level option.  If bmcweb-logging-level is
                  not set, all level (i.e. debug) of traces are enabled'
So this only works if the option above is true? Can you add more detail here..

It is modified to add option description like:

    description: 'Specify the level of the extended logs as follows.
                  - debug : enables all of bmcweb log traces.
                  - info : enables the log traces with info or higher level including info, warning, error, or critical levels.
                  - warning : enables the log traces with warning or higher level.
                   - error :  enables the log traces with error or higher level.
                   - critical :  enables the log traces with critical level'
Why a new option instead of switching the existing one to an enum ?

I have thought it -- by changing bmcweb-logging as 'combo' field instead of keeping the current bmcweb-logging as 'feature' [enabled/disabled] like
  -Dbmcweb-logging=debug|info|warning|error|warning.

I updated meson_options.txt like

```
option(
    'bmcweb-logging',
    type: 'combo',
    choices : [ 'disabled', 'debug', 'info', 'warning', 'error', 'critical' ],
    value: 'disabled',
    description: 'Enable output the extended logging level.
                  - disabled: disable bmcweb log traces.
                  - debug :  enables all of bmcweb log traces.
                  - info: enables the informational traces and
                        warning/error/critical log traces as described below.
                  - warning: enables the traces of the undesirable or unintended conditions,
                       and error/critical log traces
                  - error: enables the severe traces like runtime errors,
                       unexpected conditions, and critical logs
                  - critical:  enables the traces of the bmcweb complete failures.'
)
```
Why remove these?

It is changed using 'if constexpr' method which will only emit the binary code
if it is true during the compilation time.

The spec / example is described in https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/if

------
Constexpr if
The statement that begins with if constexpr is known as the constexpr if statement.

In a constexpr if statement, the value of condition must be a contextually converted constant expression of type bool (until C++23)an expression contextually converted to bool, where the conversion is a constant expression (since C++23). 
*** If the value is true, then statement-false is discarded (if present), otherwise, statement-true is discarded ***

--------

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52433953/using-constexpr-to-replace-define-and-ifdef-for-conditional-compilation



Essentially, from the code generation point of view, the <body of the code> will not be generated.


    Logger([[maybe_unused]] const std::string& prefix,
           [[maybe_unused]] const std::string& filename,
           [[maybe_unused]] const size_t line, LogLevel levelIn) :
        level(levelIn)
    {
#ifdef BMCWEB_ENABLE_LOGGING
       ....<code body>
#endif

==>

>constexpr isLoggingEnabled() function will be evaluated as true
during the compilation, if BMCWEB_ENABLE_LOGGING is defined.
Otherwise, it will be false (during the compile).

    constexpr static bool isLoggingEnabled()
    {
#ifdef BMCWEB_ENABLE_LOGGING
        return true;
#else
        return false;
#endif
    }

    Logger([[maybe_unused]] const std::string& prefix,
           [[maybe_unused]] const std::string& filename,
           [[maybe_unused]] const size_t line, LogLevel levelIn) :
        level(levelIn)
    {
        if constexpr (crow::Logger::isLoggingEnabled()) 
        {  
       ==> By the compiler, this code will be discarded if isLoggingEnabled() is false.
           ... <code body>
        }
    }

This approach (using if constexpr) also helps to reduce the binary output size with LOGGING macros, esp if the debug or logging level is not enabled.

Taking an example like this logging code

```
           BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG << "Request failed to construct" << reqEc;
```

This original logging macro will generate the binary code even if it may not execute at the runtime.

```
#define BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG \
if (crow::Logger::getCurrentLogLevel() <= crow::LogLevel::Debug) \
crow::Logger("DEBUG", FILE, LINE, crow::LogLevel::Debug)
```

However, with this new constexpr approach, the logging part won't be generated into the binary.
```
#define BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG \
if constexpr (crow::Logger::checkLoggingLevel(crow::LogLevel::Debug)) \
crow::Logger("CRITICAL", FILE, LINE, crow::LogLevel::Debug)
```

As the result, bmcweb binary size will become smaller (if debug is not enabled).

Here is the binaries with old/new approach as an example
```
- 159708372 bmcweb    // with old #ifdef macro
- 158467232 bmcweb    // with 'if constexpr'
```
The approach (if constexpr) is doing the same effect (like #ifdef), but I'm going to revive to use #ifdef BMCWEB_ENABLE_LOGGING as it was.

The meson option also allows 'enabled' or 'disabled' for the compatibility of the existing choices.  If it is not set, it is considered as 'disabled'.

'enabled' is interpreted as 'debug' (i.e. current default).

If it is 'disabled', logging is disabled like how it is working as today.
If it is 'enabled', the log level is meaningful and used in the code.

If a certain level of logging is needed, the appropriate option needs to be specified - from one of log level choices, i.e. explicit log level setting is required.
Forgot to mention, the default value for 'logging' is 'disabled'.

This is another place where we're mixing ifdef and contexpr.  Please pick one or another, mixing them causes this code to be hard to read.

Why did this ifdef move?

Why is this constexpr needed?  We're mixing ifdefs and constexpr if here.  I'd prefer we stick to one or the other for clarity, with a minor preference for if constexpr for everything, but I realize that's a larger change.

Also, why doesn't this check the level like the other ifdefs?

isLoggingEnabled() can be a constexpr as all necessary values are available at compile-time.
However, checkLoggingLevel() can not be evaluated at a time, as the input 'loglevel' to Logger (current implementation) is not a constant.

Because of that, I first check isLoggingEnabled() as constexpr.  This approach will reduce the binary output size in case debugging is not enabled.

I'll also look more to see whether isLoggingEnabled() and checkLoggingLevel() can be combined as constexpr.

> checkLoggingLevel() can not be evaluated at a time

Logging level is a compile time constant, it should be able to be constexpr?  if checkLoggingLevel is contexpr, I suspect we'll get the same result.

How do we see critical, error logs if the default is disabled. Is that correct default?

The existing default is "disabled".  Keeping that way minimizes message spam.

You have to specify it as a compiler option.  Adding this to your bbappend will enable logging only critical and error messages:

EXTRA_OEMESON:append = " \
     -Dbmcweb-logging=error \
"
Make sense. Thanks! Myung, Do we need to change these recipes?

Carson, thanks for he response.

Ninad,
Yes, the exploiter needs to set the appropriate level in the recipes.

No, I am worried that we are changing the default. Today by default there is no entry in the recipe so it will go with default from the bmcweb and the bmcweb default is disabled so we will stop seeing errors and critical messages. Is that true?
I think we need to make recipe change first otherwise we will loose the critical error messages.

Yes, that's true.
In upstream, the default is disabled if logging-level is not specified in recipe.
If the other level is needed, it needs to be specified in the recipe.

(Just for the reference, ibm-openbmc/bmcweb currently modifies src/webserver_main.cpp to set it as 'error'. But in the future, it can be done via recipe)

Just for the clarification, in upstream, error/critical messages are also disabled by default.

This commit does not change the default behavior (i.e.  it remains as 'disabled').

It is up to downstream which logging levels are to be enabled.
